intro.title: Postcard Generator
intro.content: Please follow the instructions provided to create your postcard.

snowflake.altText: The crystaline structure of a 6-sided snowflake.

instructions.content: First, tap an image to select a background.

This is your selected background image. You can choose another background image or move to the next step and take a photo of yourself.  Be sure you've given permission for the app to use your camera and photo gallery!

withimage.content: This is your photo.  Nice shot!  You can retake your photo or write your message.  Please limit to 140 characters or less.

message.label: Message
message.placeholder_text: Example: Hi Mom!  I just visited the NCAR Visitor Center and played with a cloud!

finished.review_text: Here is your postcard.  Would you like to send it?

intro.content: The NCAR Visitor Center is located at the NCAR Mesa Lab in Boulder, Colorado. Admission is always free.

hours.title: Visitor Center Hours
hours.content:
Weekdays: 8:00 am - 5:00 pm
Weekends: 9:00 am - 4:00 pm
Holidays: 9:00 am - 4:00 pm

The visitor center is open every day except for two annual shut down days in the spring and fall. Please view our visitor website prior to your visit for updated information.

cafeteria.title: Cafeteria Hours
cafeteria.content:
Breakfast, 8:00 am - 9:30 am
Lunch, 11:30 - 1:30 pm

The cafeteria is open weekdays only, except holidays. The cafeteria accepts cash and credit card.

restrooms.title: Public Restrooms
restrooms.content:
Men's Restroom

Men's restrooms are located:

  • On the north end of the first floor, directly across from the front desk
  • On the north end of the second floor, north of the Climate Futures exhibit
  • On the south end of the 2nd floor, in the hallway just north of the Library

Women's Restrooms

Women's restrooms are located:

  • On the south end of the 1st floor, in the hallway directly behind the theater
  • On the norht end of the 2nd floor, north of the Climate Futures exhibit
  • On the south end of the 2nd floor, down the hallway and to the right, behind the library

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.content: The NCAR Mesa Lab Visitor Center is committed to opening its doors to everyone, including those with disabilities along with their families and friends.  Our Visitor program is committed to ensuring an inclusive environment which promotes learning and enjoyment for visitors with diverse interests, abilities, and needs.  Additional information about our accessibility accomodations can be found on our visitor website.

parking.title: Parking
parking.content: NCAR's Mesa Lab Visitor Center offers two entrances for those with mobility impairments and their companions.
parking.content1: This is a secure driveway and entrance, therefore one must call NCAR (303-497-1139) in advance to gain access to the two accessible parking spaces or to drop visitors off at the main entrance.
parking.content2: The second option is to park in the accessible parking area at the back (south side) of the building directly next to our delivery dock. Please buzz the intercom located next to the inside door and our security staff will facilitate your entrance. (Please feel free to ask via the intercom for a staff escort to meet you at this entrance if desired.) All doors in this area are automatic. Once inside, follow the green dots to the elevator. Enter the elevator, press "G" for Ground Level, and it will transport you to the first floor of our Visitor Center.

elevators.title: Elevators
elevators.content: All exhibits and public areas are accessible by elevator. Elevators are located on the north and south sides of the climate and weather exhibits.  Please inquire with the front desk if you need directions.

restrooms.title: Restrooms
restrooms.content: A wheelchair accessible restroom is available on the second floor, north of the Climate Future exhibit area.

content.title: Clouds
content.description: Our view of the sky is constantly changing as clouds form and evolve. Clouds form when air rises from the Earth’s surface and cools, causing water vapor to condense on tiny particles in the atmosphere. Take a look out the window to observe whether there are clouds in the sky!

content.title: Severe Weather
content.description: Severe weather includes tornadoes, thunderstorms, snowstorms, hurricanes, and very strong winds. These dramatic events can impact human health and the economy. Between 1980 and 2016, over 200 weather- or climate-related events in the U.S. have caused damages that cost at least one billion dollars.

content.title: Weather Instruments
content.description: Anemometers are instruments that measure the speed of wind. Some anemometers also include a weather vane to show which direction the wind is blowing. The highest wind speed ever recorded here at the NCAR Mesa Lab was a 147 mph gust on January 23, 1971!

content.title: Microburst
content.description: Microbursts are powerful, downward winds that form very suddenly underneath thunderstorms. These downdrafts can have speeds over 100 mph! Because microbursts are a safety hazard for airplanes during takeoff or landing, NCAR scientists developed a microburst detection system in the 1980s that makes air travel much safer.

content.title: Forecasting
content.description: Weather forecasts influence our daily lives, helping us decide what to wear or when to take precautions due to upcoming severe weather. Weather forecasting models are used to predict weather in the near future. These models are run on advanced computers, and then the results are analyzed and interpreted by meteorologists.

content.title: Tornado
content.description: The most violent of all severe storms, tornadoes are columns of air rotating dangerously fast. About 75% of the world’s tornadoes form in the United States, mainly in the spring and summer in an area in the central U.S. called Tornado Alley.

content.title: Weather and Climate
content.description: The graph of temperatures in Boulder on the Fourth of July shows how weather changes from year to year. Climate is the word scientists use for long-term trends in weather. Boulder’s climate tells us that the high temperature next year on July 4th will probably be somewhere between 80 and 95 degrees Fahrenheit.

content.title: Chaos
content.description: This unusual pendulum illustrates the scientific concept of chaos. In chaotic systems. a very slight change in starting conditions affects what happens next. Weather is a chaotic system, which makes it hard to predict with complete accuracy. Spin the pendulum and try to predict its motion!

content.title: Greenhouse Gases
content.description: Charles David Keeling began measuring carbon dioxide (CO2) levels on Hawaii’s Mauna Loa Observatory in 1958. These measurements make up the Keeling Curve, which shows that CO2 values have increased from 330 to over 400 parts per million (ppm). Greenhouse gases, like CO2, trap heat in the atmosphere, warming the climate.

content.title: Past Climates
content.description: How do we learn what Earth’s climate was like a thousand or a million years ago? There is evidence of past climates preserved in glaciers, corals, and ocean sediments. Tree rings of different widths tell us about growing conditions from year-to-year. Was it dry or wet? Cool or hot?

content.title: Our Changing Climate
content.description: The Earth’s climate is changing. Global average temperature is warming due to an increase in greenhouse gases, which are released as we burn fossil fuels. Warmer temperatures are changing the character of storms, increasing the chance of drought and flooding in many areas of the world.

content.title: Choose Our Future
content.description: The choices we make today will impact our planet tomorrow! The interactive Choose Our Future game gives you feedback on how choices made in daily life impact your carbon footprint. Learn how your actions can impact the Earth’s global average temperature.

content.title: Climate Impacts
content.description: The impacts of climate change are already occurring and will continue into the future. They affect people and places around the world in many different ways. As temperatures rise and patterns of precipitation change we face a multitude of challenges. Fortunately scientists, engineers, city planners, and others are working on solutions to keep people safe.

content.title: Future Climate Predictions
content.description: The global average temperature has been rising for more than a century. Earth will continue to warm in the years ahead unless humans dramatically reduce our emission of greenhouse gases. Using renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, instead of fossil fuels could help us achieve those reductions.

content.title: Climate Solutions
content.description: There are many ways to address the challenges associated with climate change. People all over the world are currently working on solutions at national, regional, and community levels in a variety of ways, such as decreasing carbon dioxide emissions and planning how to best deal with the impacts of climate change.

content.title: History of Solar Research
content.description: This mural provides the history of NCAR’s High Altitude Observatory (HAO) since its founding in the 1940s. In this timeline (with years listed along the bottom), HAO’s milestones appear across the center of the mural, with major space exploration events above, and technical advancements  below.

content.title: Observing the Sun
content.description: The beautiful displays of colorful lights in the sky that we know as the Northern Lights, or aurora, are caused by powerful magnetic disturbances on the Sun. Changes in the Sun’s intense magnetic field produce solar activity such as sunspots (like the one at the right), prominences, and Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs), which disrupt Earth’s protective magnetosphere.

content.title: Layers of the Atmosphere
content.description: Earth’s atmosphere extends hundreds of miles upward until it fades into outer space. However, more than 80% of the atmosphere’s mass and almost all clouds and weather occur in the lowest layers, within 10 miles of the ground. That is down around knee level on this mural!

content.title: Dropsondes
content.description: Weather stations are great for recording data about the atmosphere at ground level. But how can scientists measure temperature, air pressure, humidity, and winds higher in the atmosphere? Dropsondes are instrument packages that are dropped from planes with small parachutes. They radio data back to scientists as they fall.

content.title: Supercomputers
content.description: Cloud desc

content.title: The Cray-1A Supercomputer
content.description: For decades, NCAR has been a pioneer in the use of supercomputers for weather and climate modeling. This Cray-1A supercomputer was a state-of-the-art machine when it arrived at NCAR in 1977. Designed by Seymour Cray, widely regarded as the father of supercomputing, this computer weighs over five tons and has one whole megabyte of memory!

content.title: Air Quality
content.description: Like the weather, air quality can change from day to day or even hour to hour, so it is important to collect frequent and accurate air pollution data. Air quality is poor when air pollution is high. Air pollution damages plants and causes respiratory problems for people.

content.title: Ozone Garden
content.description: Ground-level ozone is the air pollutant that causes the most damage to plants. Some plants are particularly sensitive to ozone and develop visible symptoms of ozone damage on their leaves that look like tiny spots. This makes them useful biological indicators of high and dangerous levels of ground-level ozone during the growing season.

content.title: COSMIC-2 Satellite
content.description: The COSMIC satellite system uses a clever trick to study Earth’s atmosphere. Radio waves are beamed from one satellite to another and bend slightly as they pass through the atmosphere. Careful study of those radio waves reveals information about temperature, humidity, pressure, and other traits of the air at different heights and around the globe.

content.title: The NCAR Library
content.description: Cloud desc

content.title: NCAR's Architecture
content.description: The NCAR Mesa Lab was designed by the renowned architect I.M Pei. Pei’s inspiration for this building came from Mesa Verde in southwest Colorado. Walter Orr Roberts, the first director of NCAR, spearheaded the effort to locate the building in Boulder. The Mesa Lab celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2017.

content.title: The Weather Trail
content.description: The Weather Trail, a short loop trail, just 0.4 miles long, includes signs describing local weather and provides spectacular views of Boulder’s Flatirons. Check out the experimental wind turbines to the southeast, and you might even see downtown Denver on a clear day.

text.title: Zoomable map of the NCAR Mesa Lab Visitor Center
text.desc: An interative map of the NCAR Visitor Center. Use the buttons or swipe and pinch gestures to move the map around and to zoom in and out.
text.descaccess: A map showing how to get to wheelchair accessible bathrooms and elevators inside of the NCAR Mesa Lab Visitor Center.

label.wheelchairramp1: Wheelchair ramp from mezzanine to 1st floor.  Take the ramp past the NCAR Architecture exhibit to the hallway.  Turn right then follow the hallway until you can turn right at NCAR security.
label.wheelchairentrance: Wheelchair entrance from disability parking spaces - enter from floor 2B and take path to elevator
label.cafeterialoc: Cafeteria and art gallery. Located on the 1st floor on the south side of the building
label.weathertrailloc: Weather Trail exit. Located on the 2nd floor on the west side of the building
label.weatherexhibitloc: Weather exhibit. Located on the 1st floor to the left of the front entrance
label.climateexhibitloc: Climate Exhibit. Located on the 2nd floor
label.securityloc: NCAR Security. Located behind the front desk to the right of the entrance on the north side of the building
label.frontdeskloc: Front desk. Located to the right of the entrance on the north side of the building
label.satelliteloc: COSMIC Satellite exhibit. Located on the mezzanine
label.archloc: NCAR's Architecture Exhibit. Located on the mezzanine, on the west between the satellite and sun-earth connections exhibit
label.sunearthloc: Sun-Earth Connections exhibit. Located on the mezzanine, north of the stairs
label.mainseminarloc: Main Seminar Room.  Located on the mezzanine to the south
label.stairsclassroom: West stairs from the 1st floor to the 2nd floor by the classroom.  Take 4 steps up to the landing, turn right, take 12 additional steps up to another landing, turn right, take 4 additional steps.
label.stairscentral2m: Central stairs from 2nd floor to the mezzanine just west of the climate exhibit.  Take 13 steps down to the landing.  To go the 1st floor lobby, turn right, take 7 additional steps down.
label.stairscentralm1: Central stairs from the mezzanine to the 1st floor lobby. Take 7 steps down.
label.stairscentral1m: Central stairs from the 1st floor lobby to the mezzanine.  Go up 7 steps.  To proceed to the 2nd floor, turn left at the landing and take 13 additional steps up.
label.stairswest21: West stairs from 2nd floor to 1st floor by the weather trail.  Take 4 steps down to the landing, turn left, take 12 steps down to another landing, turn left, take 4 additional steps
label.stairsnwarch: Northwest stairs to floor 1B from mezzanine between the architecture and supercomputing exhibits. From the hallway railing, take 11 steps down to the landing, turn right, take 7 additional steps.
label.stairsnw1bm: Northwest stairs from floor 1B to the mezzanine between the supercomputing and architecture exhibits.  Take 7 steps up to the landing, turn left, take 11 additional steps up to the next landing, turn right, walk along hallway until to you reach 4 additional steps.
label.stairssouththeater: South stairs from the 1st floor to the second floor next to the theater. Take 6 steps up to the landing, turn right, 8 additional steps up to another landing, turn right, take 6 additional steps.
label.stairssouthcray: South stairs from floor 1B to the 1st floor between the Cray-1A supercomputer and the weather exhibits.  Take 6 steps up to the landing, turn right, take 8 steps up to another landing, turn right, take 6 additional steps.
label.stairssouth11b: South stairs from the 1st floor to floor 1B between the Cray-1A supercomputer and the weather exhibits.  Take 6 steps down to the landing, turn left, take 8 steps to another landing, turn left, take 6 additional steps.
label.stairssouth21: South stairs from 2nd floor to 1st floor by the Atmosphere exhibit.  Take 6 steps down to the landing, turn left, take 8 additional steps to another landing, turn left, take 6 additional steps.
label.stairseast21: East stairs from the 1st floor to the 2nd floor by the cafeteria.  Take 4 steps up to the landing, turn left, take 12 additional steps to another landing, turn left, take 4 additional steps.
label.stairseast12: East stairs from 2nd floor to 1st floor behind the library. Take 4 steps down to the landing, turn right, take 12 additional steps to another landing, turn right, take 4 additional steps.
label.rampto1: Ramp to 1st floor.  Take the ramp down, turn right at the end of the hallway, and turn right by the NCAR Security desk to return to the 1st floor exhibits.
label.artsci1: Art-Science - 2nd floor gallery.  Located just before the weather trail exit.
label.artsci2: Art-Science - 1st floor gallery. Located in the hallway west of the climate exhibit.
label.lobbyloc: Lobby - located directly inside the front entrance
label.classroomloc: Classroom. Located off the hallway between the back of the cafeteria and the art-science gallery on the 1st floor
label.theaterloc: Theater. Located south of the climate exhibit just before the stairs to the Atmosphere exhibit
label.toweathertrail: Go west outside the doors to the weather trail
label.atmloc: ATM. located just outside the cafeteria entrance on the 1st floor on the south east side of the building
label.picnicloc: Picnic Area. Located outside from the cafeteria entrance on the 1st floor on the south east side of the building
label.elevator1theater: Elevator. 1st Floor. Located directly across from the theater next to the stairs
label.elevator1bcray: Elevator. Floor 1B. Located directly west of the CRAY-1A supercomputer exhibit
label.elevator2library: Elevator. 2nd floor. Located directly across from the library next to the stairs
label.elevator2climate: Elevator. 2nd floor. Located in the hallway north of the climate exhibit
label.elevator1front: Elevator. 1st floor. Located in the hallway north of the front desk
label.elevator1bsupercomputing: Elevator. Floor 1B. Located in the hallway next to the supercomputing exhibit
label.brmen1front: men's bathroom located on the 1st floor across from the front desk
label.brm2climate: men's bathroom located on the 2nd floor north of the climate exhibit
label.brmen2library: men's bathroom located on the 2nd floor in the hallway between the climate exhibit and library
label.brwomen2climate: women's bathroom located on 2nd floor north of the climate exhibit
label.brwomen2library: women's bathroom located on 2nd floor down the hallway behind the library
label.brwomen1theater: women's bathroom located on the 1st floor in the hallway between the weather exhibit and the theater
label.braccess2: accessible bathroom located on the 2nd floor north of the climate exhibit
label.braccess1: accessible bathroom located on the 1st floor across from the front desk
label.atmos1loc: Atmosphere exhibit. Located on the stairs between the 1st and second floors, south of the weather and climate exhibits
label.atmos2loca: Atmosphere exhibit. Located on the stairs between the 1st and second floors, south of the weather and climate exhibits
label.libraryloc: Library. Located on the 2nd floor just south of the Climate exhibit
label.aqloc: Air Quality Exhibit. Located just to the left of the lobby on the 1st floor
label.gardenloc: Ozone garden. Located outside, left of the front entrance
label.crayloc: CRAY-1A Supercomputer exhibit. Located on Floor 1B down the stairs from the theater
label.supercomputingloc: Supercomputing exhibit. Located on Floor 1B down the ramp from the Mezzanine
